name: wendy macnaughton
bio: Drawing, graphic journoing, social working, etc. Creator @drawtogether.studio & Grown-Ups Table (The GUT!) New book “How to Say Goodbye” out now. 🏳️‍🌈

social_posts.post_text:
Artist Pets:
1. Suso 
2. Hockney with Stanley & Boogie. 
3. O’Keefe with Bo and Chia. 
4. Bearden with Mikie. 
5. Warhol with Archie. 
6. Kahlo with her deer. 
7. Matisse with one of his three cats. 
8. Wiley with Liza and Lord Compton. 
9. Picasso with Lump. 
10. Foujita with one of his many cats. 
This week on the #drawtogethergut I shared the pet portraits made by their artist humans (have you seen Warhols many Archie portraits?! Or Hockney’s hundreds of Weiner dogs?!) and invited everyone to create their own. Usually I lean more into the art history or technical or emo realms, but this week has been tough and all I really want is to see drawings of everyone’s sweet animals. So I’m being selfish. So far the drawings GUT members are sharing are 😭😭😭. If you want to join in, link is in my bio. If you can’t afford the $, message me. No GUTs left behind. ❤️✏️❤️

Today on the DT Grown-Ups Table: a studio visit and conversation with one of my fave artists in the world Tucker Nichols @tuckernichols. Tucker answers a ton of my questions, let’s us be nosy (I photographed and videotaped all the corners and drawers and shelves, oh my!) and shares fave art supplies, philosophies, all that good stuff, and gives us our weekly GUT drawing assignment. Thank you Tucker!! Subscribe to the GUT at the link in my bio.
Thank you @carolinembpaul for editing the Tucker studio visit video.

#drawtogethergut 
@drawtogether.studio

New DT Merch just dropped! LINK IN BIO. 

Super cozy Bella + Canvas hand-screened sweatshirts, 100% made local in California! Zippers for grown-ups and pullovers for kids. And PINS!!! 😍 GUT members look for a discount in the DrawTogether Gift Guide via today’s DT Newsletter. A portion of all proceeds go to support DrawTogether Classrooms, DT’s non-profit that delivers SEL-focused art programming to schools, libraries, and other learning environments around the country. 
HUGE cheers for @itstaylorle for updating the DT logo (so snaz, right?) and @patrickdrawsthings for designing the merch and building the DT shop. And thank you @tinydeerstudio & @thepindept for managing all the backend goodness! And of course @annehattie for the 📸 
BEST MERCH EVER
❤️🌈✏️🙏😍

A few wonderful books by or about artists we featured in the DT Podcast & DT Grown-Ups Table (the GUT!) in 2022. If you missed any of them head to the newsletter. Pick up a book by/about these artists and other special art supply gift stuff at your local indi book and art store. Links in the latest GUT newsletter, no paywall.🤘🤘🤘

Gotta be real this has been my worst holiday/December yet. I’m on my tenth day quarantining (still positive as of yesterday, and ran out of tests!) alone in a little house with covid over the holiday. The isolation with a hellscape backdrop of life events nearly broke me. I know I’m part of a very large very crappy club of astoundingly strong people who are/have also been sick and sad and scared this holiday, away from their loved ones, going through the roughest stuff, and/or feeling super lonely. Go team. But time is a miracle and today I woke up and it finally feels it’s gonna be okay, even if it’s not right now.
Lessons I’m taking from this: let people show up. Accept kindnesses without question. Ask for help. If you have the energy, make something. And CUDDLE AN ANIMAL. Thank goodness for little Suso who snores like a freight train. And thank extra thankness for loving friends and family and Caroline - who showed up in so many ways (Food! Medical! Treats! Gifts! Daily check ins/life checks! Animal delivery!) and showed me so much love.
This is the drawing of my holiday that I shared with the #drawtogethergut. Suso sends her love. I do too. Thank you thank you thank you.

Did you know I host a weekly drawing exploration/lesson that’s turned out to be the most awesome supportive community of creative folks who want to draw more? It’s called the GUT. Short for Grown-Ups Table. Every Sunday I send out a dispatch on art/drawing/life stuff - what I’m excited about, looking at, etc, or sometimes a straight up drawing lesson (like todays back to basics lesson on negative space) and sometimes we have visiting artists or studio visits… Then I give an assignment and we all share our drawings in a chat where we can comment and support each other and it’s kind of the best thing ever. And we are all over the world. (Waving to the person who just joined in Tasmania!) It’s $6 a month and you can join in at the link in my bio. Look for the “DT Grown-Ups Table.”

Images here are from todays lesson on negative space. Do you know about the hidden image in slide #2? Once you see it you can’t see anything else. 

And hey, #drawtogethergut peeps: thanks for making the GUT so special and fun. Onwards together in 2023❤️✏️🙏

Slides on negative space: 
1. Egon Schiele
2. Logo by Lindon Leader
3. Rachel Whiteread
4. W.E.B. Du Bois
5. More Egon Schiele
6. Katsushika Hokusai 
7. Andrew Wyeth

Slideshows were one of my fave parts of class in art school. Little did I know how totally subjective they are, and how much they said about the professor and their interests and biases. Well, mine are sure showing! This week in the GUT we start looking/learning about Line - the seven types of lines, abstract and representational, even a little neuroscience on how we see and why we draw outlines. Above are the examples I used. These also happen to be some of my fave artists. Also turns out this #drawtogethergut thing is a fun an excuse to share amazing art here, instead of being all self-promo, while still encouraging you to *sign up for the GUT bc I think it’s way worth the $6/mo.* 
Yeah, not self-promotional at all. 🥸LINK IN BIO🚨🚨🚨
Drawings by:
1. Joan Brown self portrait line drawing, age 20 (go see her show of paintings at @sfmoma!) 
2. Bridgette Riley abstract op-art drawing (technically a gouache painting, but fight me I call it a drawing, it deals with elements of drawing we discuss in the #drawtogethergut this dispatch) 
3. Ellsworth Kelly plant drawings 🤩😭
4. Ruth Asawa abstract drawing related to her 3D wire drawings in air 
5. Ben Shahn drawing ink on paper 🤯😭
6. Cy Twombly abstract painting that is line drawing 
7. Picasso continuous line drawing

Last week in the #drawtogethergut we took inspiration from @annahoyleart @nathanielrussell @jottoseibold Saul Steinberg and  @stoppingoffplace and we drew an entire library of Imaginary Books. Every one is fun, funny and kind of profound. Swipe to see a small selection. Mine is the last one and kind of wraps up the bedroom painting adventure you might have seen me taking in my stories last week. 😫🙄❤️ If you wanna join the GUT the link is in my bio.
Found an old cheat sheet.

In medieval times people believed that rays of light shot out of our eyes and illuminated the world. It’s called “emission theory” and while it might sound ridiculous, we wouldn’t draw, design or build the way we do today without it. See those rays in the first image, in that etching? Those lines became the basis for our entire system for drawing perspective.🤯
This weeks #drawtogetherGUT is an unscary easy hopefully fun intro on drawing in perspective. (Which, btw, I nearly failed in art school.) We learn the basics and how to draw in 1 point perspective. And if everyone doesn’t run away and immediately unsubscribe, we’ll do a quick dive into 2 & 3 point in the future. 
Swipe for a few of the images we look at and our assignment we’ll share in the chat over the next week. And if you want to become a GUT member, hit the link in my bio. ❤️
1. Emission Theory, Johann Zahn, 1685
2. “School of Beauty,School of Culture”, Kerry James Marshall, 2012
3. Canaletto, 1740 (from The History of Pictures)
4. The four elements of perspective in one crappy drawing 
5. GUT assignment glimpse
6. Two NY Stories 
7. The Road West, Dorothea Lange, 1939

Somehow this makes the student loans hurt a little less! My social work grad school @columbia’s alumni mag @columbiamagazine did such a generous and thoughtful and in depth profile of my unusual trajectory - art to advertising to social work to drawing to stories to professional art goofball to some messy stew of them all. The brilliant (and patient!) CD @lenpsmall had the fun idea for me to diagram it out for the article, and writer Rebecca Shapiro did such a great job making sense of my mess in her clean, beautiful writing. (Bless you both.) 
While I might not suggest people go to an Ivy League school to study social work, I’m an evangelist for the field and practice, and the unlikely but obvious-once-you-see-it intersection of art/social work/stories. So I’m so happy to get news about this kind of work and opportunities further out into the world. And I’m super proud and honored to be a Columbia alum. ❤️🙏
Bonus: Best DT set photo by @alannahale and rad cover by @jkroik !! ❤️🙏

In last week’s #drawtogethergut we drew self-portrait charts and in my blah-blah-talking part I shared these two charts, one by me the other by @davidshrigley, and I love how these venns, like all of us, are two sides of the same silly coin. 
Happy Sunday to those that celebrate. (This weeks GUT is about personal color and Alma Thomas and @bisabutler. Link to join in the bio.)

This beautiful memoir by this beautiful human inside and out launches today! Congrats @laurel_braitman and thank you for pouring all your heart and hurt and hope and love into these pages. We are/ l am so inspired by you. ❤️❤️

Big big news: DRAWTOGETHER CLASSROOMS IS HERE! For nearly two years we’ve been hard at work creating a program to help educators bring art and social emotional learning to their classrooms - and today it’s finally here! And in keeping with the DrawTogether spirit, we are offering the resources, material and support to all educators FOR FREE. Link to learn all about DrawTogether Classrooms in my bio. Help us get the word out and share with educators and libraries and homeschoolers and Ed orgs around the country! ❤️✏️❤️
Huge shout out to @kontentfilms and @catwisepdx for the awesome DT Classrooms videos you’ll see roll out over the next few weeks. And giant cheers to all the folks who contributed to make this happen (there are so many of us!) and most especially DT’s director of Ed & Impact @katelevitt (YAY KATE!!) for all her hard work bringing this program to life! PENCILS UP!👏👏👏

Today’s Grown-Ups Table drawing/life lesson takes a cue on self-care from Miley Cyrus and recommends the cinema classic “The Fugitive.” Spoiler alert: Turns out the world will not stop spinning if you do. (But your drawing could improve!) Link in bio. #drawtogethergut #icanbuymyselfflowers

ICYMI: DrawTogether Classrooms is here! And it’s FREE. In less than a week, over 400 educators have already signed up. Our first Art Assembly for educators is Thursday 3/23 (swipe for more info.) Know an educator who deserves some help bringing art and social emotional learning to their classroom? Pass this on. 
Our goal is to reach 10k classrooms. That’s 300,000+ kids with increased curiosity, care, confidence, and creativity. Join in and help us spread the word. ❤️✏️❤️
Via the notorious @jerrysaltz
Iris explosion

THIS BEAUTIFUL BOOK MADE BY THIS BRILLIANT SHINING STAR OF A HUMAN! I love them both so much!!!! Congrats to @ishitajain24 on the launch of her magnificent book, many years on the making. “Searching for Sunshine” is a drawn exploration into all things plants and the people who love them - stories and drawings all plucked from real life, all centered in NYC. For anyone who loves nature and is curious about people (which is to say anyone w a pulse) this beautiful book is for you. 
It’s been one of my biggest lifetime joys to be in conversation with Ishita since she started working on this book. I was her thesis advisor when she was getting her masters at @svanyc (that’s where this book began!) And now it’s the first book she’s written and drawn cover to cover (attn grad students, thesis into book: with a ton of hard work it’s possible!) And it was beyond an honor to write the foreword. 
Ishita, I’m thrilled the world will get to know your joyful, curious, ebullient spirit with this book - all the thoughtful interviews and your gorgeous location drawings, each one created with attention, care and delight. And I’m so darn proud to call you my mentee (is that a word?) and more, my friend. So, so much congrats on a huge accomplishment and important contribution. Love you!! ❤️✏️👀🌱❤️

Y’all know about the Grown-Ups Table? Every Sunday I send out a new drawing lesson and assignment, and folks share their drawings and encourage each other in a substack chat. It’s kind of the best, most supportive creative community on the internet. All experience levels welcome, curiosity required. Subscribe via the DrawTogether newsletter - link in my bio. The quote is from last weeks lesson and assignment on drawing food memories.✏️👀❤️

RIP cartoonist Ed Koren. Old school pen and ink drawer of beasts and humans and ironies. His books with Delia Ephron were my favorite when I was a kid. Thank you Ed & @newyorkermag for decades of laughs.

We don’t look at each other anymore. Drawing can help. It slows us down, helps us pay attention, and connects us to each other and the world. Yesterday afternoon I set up a little drawing booth in downtown SF and invited people who don’t know each other to draw together. So many people took me up on it that I ran out of paper. 
I’ll be doing it again in SF on Sunday. Watch my stories for location. ❤️

**UPDATE: I’m working on a public toolkit for this project. If you’re interested in hosting, sign up for the Grown-Ups Table in my bio. Free option is fine.** Welp, it works. Day 2 of strangers drawing/looking closely at each other was a huge success. Thanks to everyone who took the leap! I’ll do more pop-ups around SF in the weeks ahead. Our city needs it. We all do. I will probably take it on the road soon, too. 
Also, people have asked if you can set up a DrawTogether Pop-Up in your own town. Answer: Soon, Yes! I’ve been working on this project for years and know what works and what doesn’t. To maintain the integrity of the experience I’m creating a set of instructions and loose script for people to use. If you’re interested in participating email me at wendy at wendy macnaughton dot com
✏️👀❤️
Thanks @seemala for the impromptu documentation!!

I’ve been waiting for this one - “America Redux” is out TODAY. @arielabergriger is one of my favorite visual storytellers/journalists. Her blend of design, analog and digital collage, photography and illustration, and her friendly, familiar and sharp minded writing makes for this wholly unique story telling experience and I just LOVE it. Think Lauren Redniss meets COLORS magazine meets Howard Zinn, but totally Ariel. “America First” is her first book, and it’s already getting all the started reviews etc, but what I’m most excited about is all the families that can read this together - it’s like a storybook for the visual generation about the myths and misunderstandings of America’s history. And there are a lot. Huge congrats @arielabergriger!!! Never stop. 
(In case that’s not enough, official blurb included at the end. I STAN.)

Who got in trouble for doodling in class? 🙋‍♀️I’m a constant doodler. I doodle while talking on the phone and during meetings. I make doodley grocery lists, to do doodle lists, electricity bill doodles. Doodles everywhere. 
I kind of just assumed everyone who draws doodles, too. But recently someone who draws told me he doesn’t doodle. WHAT?? He said he doesn't know how. My heart broke a little. 
I thought doodling was hard baked into every visual person. Don’t we all mindlessly cover every surface with flowers and stars? Don’t we all relax by letting our pens flow into unexpected shapes and designs?? Maybe not after all. 
This made me wonder: What is a doodle? And what makes a doodler doodle? Why doodle at all? Can a non-doodler become a doodler? And what do doodles DOOOO? 
This week on the Grown-Ups Table, we take a deep dive into the science of doodles and share some that have proven to calm the nervous system, improve memory and enhance creativity. And stuff. I mean come on, it’s scientific and all, sure. But it’s also just doodles.
Join us at the Grown-Ups Table - link in bio!
Note to all of us.

That’s my beautiful, curious, thoughtful, supportive, cheerful mom. You meet all the toughest challenges with open-hearted love and laughter, and all the Kodak commercials with tears. Thanks for showing me what resilience really looks like: meeting everything life hands us, all the ups and downs, with kindness, generosity, and gratitude, every darn day. I am the luckiest daughter. Love you up in the sky.

One of the things I respect about Dave-flip-phone-Eggers is his complete unawareness of impossibility. When he showed me this cut wooden cover a year ago I asked him, “how is that even possible??” He said, “I saw it somewhere and said, I want to do that. So we figured out how to do it.” I think many of us let lack of resources stop us from imagining things, let alone making them. That’s a mistake. If we can imagine something, it’s possible. If it’s possible, we can make it. That’s making art. 
Congrats Dave and @shawnharri5 and @mcswys on The Eyes and The Impossible, and on making impossible objects for decades and inspiring us all to do the same.

Y’all know I have a weekly art/drawing class online where I explore subjects I’m interested in/looking at/reading about, right? And that I give a weekly a drawing assignment and members can share their art and offer support to each other in a chat? And that it’s *the best community on the internet*?? (Ask around - it’s true!) It’s called the Grown-Ups Table, and it’s kind of like DrawTogether but for grown-ups. And it’s all on @substackinc so it’s easy to keep up, interact, move at your own pace, etc. 
This week, I brought subscribers along on a trip to New York’s galleries and museums to look up close at some of my favorite work. Secret: you can always if tell someone is an artist by how close they get to the work. It’s only by getting up close and really LOOKING and paying attention to *how* the artist made the work that we can really understand a work of art. This week features artists @bisabutler @markbradfordart Van Gogh and Georgia O’Keefe. These are all closeups of work you may/may not be familiar with. Either way, looking close is seeing anew. 
(Bonus pic: an artist draws from marble-life at the Met)
Link to join the Grown-Ups Table in my bio. ❤️
Artwork on view at @hauserwirth @jeffreydeitchgallery @metmuseum @themuseumofmodernart

Life has so many darn textures and not all of them are smooth. Might as well learn to draw them. This week’s Grown-Ups Table is all about texture: actual, implied and impasto (impasto!) and learning to create implied texture and value (light/shadow) w just a pen and paper. Presto! 
Some examples we use and more:
1. Lucian Freud, impasto 
2. Andrew Wyeth, implied 
3. Chuck Close (blargh), implied 
4. Camille Claudel, actual 
5. Vincent Van Gogh, impasto! 
6. Joan Brown, impasto
7. Jay Defeo, impasto x100
8. The GUT, implied! 
9. The GUT, implied! 
I love doing these little art lessons so much. Link to join in —> in my bio.❤️✏️
#drawtogethergut

400 year old abandoned maze in Spain. Via @studio_magga UPDATE: *Not abandoned!* This is Pazo De San Lorenzo and it’s beautifully maintained and cared for. Thank you @tiwa_select and amazing landscaper Anne Simpson for the correction. 🌳

Nobody does anything in true isolation. And some of us need a little more structure and accountability to get going. I’ve fallen out of my daily drawing practice (and drawing is my job! Identity! It happens to all of us) and I wanted a way to get back into it - so I started a 30-day drawing group over on the DrawTogether Grown-Ups Table.  We just started today! (Join us anytime.) Members get a new assignment each week to use as a launch for a 10-minute morning drawing, and we’ll use the chat as space to gather, share our drawings and discuss daily/weekly/whenever you want to check in. The GUT community is so great and I think this month is going to be extra special. Also, full disclosure: it’s also a little personal experiment. I want to see how regular drawing like this can change our brains, hearts and bodies. So welcome to my drawing lab. There may be surveys. :) 
30 Days of Drawing - Link to join the Grown-Ups Table in the Chat❤️✏️❤️WELCOME.

10 days into the 30-day Drawing Habit challenge over on the DrawTogether Grown-Ups Table on Substack! We got hundreds (thousands!) of people drawing together for *ten minutes a day* and sharing our work with each other for support, community and accountability. It’s not too late to join! Link in my bio. Intimidated? Thinking “I can’t draw!”?? I got you. This is NOT about making “good” drawings, friends. This is about making the time to DRAW, and focusing on the actual DOING of it because it feels so darn good in our brains and bodies and hearts. I started it because I needed it myself. We’re doing it together. Just ten minutes a day. And this week we are doing blind contour drawings so I promise everyone’s are terrible. And hilarious and fun and AWESOME. 
Join ussssss. Link in bio. 
#drawtogethergut 
Ps - i cheated on the black and white one. Sue me. NO RULES IN ART.

So this is happening and it feels extra personal: I have a new book coming out next month. It’s called “How to Say Goodbye.” It’s watercolor and pencil drawings coupled with the words of hospice caregivers, and it’s like a quiet little visual poem about how to be present with someone at the end of their life. Or anytime in life, really. It’s the book I once wanted/needed but it didn’t exist. I hope it can be helpful to you if/when you need it someday, too. 

The book is based on my time as the Artist in Residence at the Zen Hospice Guest House. It features drawings from inside the house - the residents, families and caregivers - paired with the words of hospice nurses and caregivers. Some of the drawings are of my own aunt Tildie, an artist and kindergarten teacher, who I drew over her last few days of life. The book shares “The Five Things” - simple but essential conversations that you can share with someone at the end of their life. Several friends used The Five Things when they were losing a loved one and found it transformative. The book has a beautiful foreword by palliative care doctor BJ Miller, and a section of helpful resources at the back. I’m so grateful to the many people who allowed themselves to be drawn and who shared their words with me, and all of YOU who offered suggestions for kids books on death and dying way back when. I included as many as I could. 

I talk a lot about how drawing helps us slow down, be present and look closely at hard things and CONNECT with people. My time with residents and families at Zen Hospice taught me a lot about that. I hope the little book can be helpful to folks who, like me, are/were (may always be!) scared to slow down and just sit with the sad painful hard scary stuff. The real deal being human stuff. 

How to Say Goodbye comes out in a month, and is available now for pre-order at the link in my bio. ❤️
18 wry smiles.

There are so many ways to paint a pool. 
I wrote about David Hockney’s pools in this week’s Grown-Ups Table, and what we can learn from his enamored focus and dazzled longing. How this Summer the better idea for our art-life might be to resist cramming in all the fun now asap before it’s too late, and instead whittle down the days to a few joyful essentials - then return to them again and again. Do less. Lie in the sun. Watch the clouds. Draw them. Then draw them again. And again. 
And again. 

Link to subscribe in my bio.

Today my new book “How to Say Goodbye” comes out. I wrote about what it means to me, and what it - and a really, really hard year - taught me about loss and letting go and making art. And, eventually, growth. (Swipe to read.) 
The little book is mostly drawings, and I’ll do another post about that and the contents of the book shortly. But today, this personal context felt right to share. 
It’s all words so 40+ fam, grab your readers. 

There is a link to buy How to Say Goodbye via an independent booksellers in my bio. Select “Bookshop” and use the code HOWTOSAY and you’ll get 10% off. Thank you @bloomsburypublishing 🙏

And finally to clarify the acronym: the GUT = the Grown-Ups Table, the weekly newsletter/art lesson/community I publish that was a lighthouse in the storm of last year. (Thx GUT peeps.) Link to join that in my bio, too. 

Book is out. Cards on the table. And with that, there you have it. 
That’s my art. 
That’s my heart. 
Onwards. ❤️

I talked with the @bostonglobe about books that’ve made an impact on me - both around drawing and end of life themes. Link in my bio.
It’s behind a paywall so I grabbed a few of the responses. Shout out to @laurel_braitman @lianafinck @alexanderlizzy @greenapplebooks @gerhard.richter @thenearsightedmonkey @rickrubin @susanmagsamen Ivy Ross, Betty Edwards, Ben Shahn and Saul Steinberg.
Photo by @alannahale ❤️

This was the best public conversation I’ve had about work, drawing, books, everything, ever. Truly. I left this interview feeling a little high. Steve Levitt of @freakonomicsradio fame has this great podcast “People I (mostly) Admire” where he talks to sciencey academic types. And for some reason he wanted to talk with this artist. First one he’s talked to in 25 years, apparently! And he and I ended up talking for hours, and he asked about things nobody ever asks me - things that make up so much of who I am as an artist - about working on the 2001 elections in Rwanda, about why drawing in Guantanamo was so emotionally challenging, about the role of joy in my work. All the Big Things, and with such deep curiosity and care. And he’s an ECONOMIST. We realized neither of us ever talks to people like each other, and a lot of our convo ended up being a compare and a contrast, which was fascinating. Anyway, I’m not known for my polished professionalism, but this conversation is probably the most open I’ve had in a while. I think, at least. I can’t listen to it. If you do, let me know if I should take down this post and pretend it never happened. But my gut feeling when I left the studio was deep love and gratitude for the chance to connect with people like Steve. 
So here it is. 
Link in my bio. 
Swipe for a pic of steve and I talking, which was a lot of just laughing and maybe me crying at one point I think? Also of course I gave a drawing assignment in the interview- the first drawing is by Steve of his wife (the first drawing he’s done in forever!!) and the second is a plant by producer Morgan. The point isn’t to make a “Good Drawing” the point is To Draw. And they did! And I even think it made them smile. ✅

There are a handful of people without whom How to Say Goodbye would not exist. In addition to the residents, nurses, caregivers and family members featured in the book, a small group of friends stayed in conversation with me as I created the project, from beginning to end. One of those folks was @mariapopova. To make something without anyone asking for it, without an editor or agent or art director or publisher is a very different experience than making something under contract. Its really all up to YOU. And, at the same time, nobody ever makes anything alone. The whole lone artist thing is a total and complete myth. For me, and this project, that small handful of people gave me feedback and encouragement from the jump. And Maria gently, continuously pushed me to share the project with a wider audience, which of course I eventually did. So it feels extra special that she wrote so beautifully about it and generously featured it in The Marginalian this week, and shared it with her thoughtful readers. Thank you Maria, and the small group of friends who encouraged me to be brave with this endeavor.
Also, maria doesn’t share pics of herself on social media but I included one we took on a road trip to Big Sur nearly 10 years ago. SORRY MARIA. I love you.

Let’s be clear. There would be no @drawtogether.studio set without Paul Reubens. I grew up watching Pee-Wees Playhouse. (Ho-meka-shalameka-hola-mala-may.) I wanted to live in that magical world where everything is possible if you’re willing to DIY the adventure. Pee-Wee was a symbol of creative freedom and subversive fun for all us arty weirdos. 
When I found out that the talented @modernhouse actually helped BUILD Pee-Wee’s Playhouse of course he was the only person who could build the DrawTogether set. And he knocked it out of the darn park. I’d ask how I got so lucky but clearly the universe has tricks up its sleeves. So many objects on the DT set were inspired by @peeweeherman’s joy and whimsy. I feel so much gratitude and debt to Paul’s creative force. Your legacy will continue to live on in the most unexpected ways. Thank you and ride that red bike all the way back home to the stars.

I miss you, my Grown-Ups Table fam! After a short Summer Vaca I’m back on the GUT train starting this Sunday. We’re having our first LIVE (online) GUT EVENT (more deets announced this Sunday) plus amazing visiting artists, nature, people, you name it. All in the name of drawing, looking and loving. And making drawing-friends. My head has been firmly planted in the clouds these past weeks, so I’m excited to get my hands back on the paper. Let’s do it together. The DT Grown-Ups Table (AKA The GUT - the weekly drawing lesson/creative community/newsletter I publish) has become such a locus of joy and support and learning and sharing that it’s high time we have a “live” meet up to connect with one another and draw together in real time. THIS SUNDAY we’re going to do an experiment and host a gathering to meet and get to know each other, do a little intro to watercolors (you asked for it, GUT!) and hang out and draw. 

This is a special experience for GUT members, which means paying subscribers. (Cost is just $6/mo.) Holler through appropriate channels if you are experiencing hardship and need a scholarship. No drawers left behind. 

This Sunday, August 20, 12pm pst on zooooommmmmm. 

Link to join the DT GUT in my bio. Link for members to register in the latest GUT newsletter! (And I’ll send another out soon.) 

We have members in over 50 countries so hope the time works for folks! 🤞 THIS IS GOING TO BE SO FUN. 

Ask Q’s below!

If you’re free at 12pm PST today and want to do a little painting together, I’m offering my first ever LIVE super basic intro to watercolor over on the DT Grown-Ups Table. Link to sign and register in my bio. 
More than Watercolor 101, this gathering is an opportunity to connect with other art/drawer people and build your/our creative community. I don’t know where I’d be without my friends who make things. And as we get older and want to get back into making stuff, a community like that can be harder to find and keep. And we’re really doing it in the GUT. And it’s making a big impact on folks. So come join us, meet some great supportive drawerly peeps, learn a little about watercolor (and how I do it all “wrong”) and draw and paint together. 

Today, Sunday 8/20, 12pm PST till 1ish (prob more like 1:20.) 
Link in bio.

New little studio. Big new smile.

On the #DrawTogetherGUT this week: COLOR. 
Color scares the crap out of me. I got a D in color class in art school. I don’t understand it at all! And I know I’m not the only one. Luckily, @lenawolffstudio is pretty darn good at using it - and teaching it - and she is our latest visiting artist on the @drawtogether.studio Grown-Ups Table. This week Lena gives us our first color lesson all about Hue and color palettes. It’s a fun, easy, fully saturated place to start. Every month for the next few months she’ll be back to go deeper until we all are straight A color students. 
Want in? Subscribe to the grown-ups table (AKA the GUT) at the link in my bio. 
Huge thanks and props as always to favorite drawing/painting/colorific shop @caseformaking for the photos (y’all check their specialty brushes and paints!) and if you want a deeper dive into color, @lenawolffstudio offers multi-day workshops on color - follow her to learn more. ❤️💛💙
COLOR!!

ICYMI this week on the DrawTogether GUT (aka the Grown-Ups Table) Visiting Artist/Naturalist John Muir Laws (aka Jack) came by to talk about drawing and attention and nature and, well, love. He shared helpful tips and tricks and offered an awesome assignment for the GUT community (which everyone seems to be loving extra hard.) And also, for three members who share their drawings in the GUT chat on @substackinc this week, Jack is offering a few insanely generous giveaways, including free tickets to the @wildwonderfoundation conference next weekend, a set of nature journaling books, and a complete nature journaling starter set worth over 500 bucks (check out that last photo!) And all you gotta do is look closely at the world and draw and share. My kind of contest. 

*Link to join the GUT in my bio & participate in the giveaway.*

Another fun fact: the brilliant author @amytanwriter credits Jack for igniting her passion for nature journaling and dedicated her forthcoming book on birdwatching (which she illustrated herself) to Fiona, a young nature journaler and colleague/friend of Jack’s. That’s them in the third photo. And that’s Fiona in the first. :) 

And please do check out the @wildwonderfoundation conference - @ishitajain24 is a keynote speaker this year, and I spoke there last year, and it was a total eye opening delight. 
All the drawings in this post are by the talented Jack himself. A wonder of nature. ❤️✏️❤️

Thank you @zachary_petit & @fastcompany for this thoughtful piece on How to Say Goodbye. I was reluctant to do press for this little book - I felt like it was gross to speak publicly about something so personal and sensitive, knowing part of the point of book promotion is to make sales, and this isn’t a book that’s about the sell sell sell. But boy was I off. The conversations I’ve been so fortunate to have w folks who happen to be journalists and podcasters and writers (and economists and neuroscientists!) have been a unique opportunity to explore the intentions and implications of this project in a way I never expected. Such a gift. And hearing how the book is landing in people’s hearts and is proving helpful in hard times… the idea of “selling the book” has faded and become more about simply letting people know it exists. As I say in DrawTogether, part of making is sharing. Clearly I need to heed my own words. Everything is an opportunity for challenge, change and growth. Not an either/or, but a yes/and. The more personal, more of a leap. Bigger the leap, bigger the growth. 
Thanks Zac for a heartfilled conversation. I hope it reaches the people who, like me, are yearning to grow. 
Link in bio, of course. :)
Yes/And. ❤️

Thank you @kqed_forum and @alexismadrigal and producer Grace Won and @judy5180 for having Ladybird Morgan and me on Forum this AM to discuss the book “How to Say Goodbye” and how we can be there for people we love at the end of life. The callers were each so open and moving and Alexis’ questions were so smart and thoughtful and I always ALWAYS love learning from the brilliant wise Ladybird (who joined us from the road! Hence the tacked-on photo.)Thank you everyone for opening your arms up to this little book - the letters and messages I receive about its impact land so deeply in my heart and even if we never meet or speak directly it’s an honor to be in conversation with you. 
Sending love, and my deepest thanks for listening/looking/reading/connecting. ❤️
Just a Monday reminder of what’s possible. How wondrous it all is. And how little we will ever understand.

I took the paywall off this weeks Grown-Ups Table drawing exercises and the GUT community chat/art share because I think we could all use a little emotional drawing support this time of year. 

Fall is hectic for everyone. Adjustments galore + future planning = high stress. I created a couple simple, short drawing exercises to help me/us pause, move out of our heads and drop into the deeper waters of our bodies and breath. One is inspired by Dr. Jud Brewer, director of the mindfulness lab at Brown, and the other is inspired by artist Ruth Asawa. In light of Fall mayhem, I figured I’d try to practice them this week and thought y’all might want to try it with me, too. 

The link to this free edition of the GUT is in my bio. And if you try it, share your drawings in the chat or post them here and tag them #drawtogetherGUT and share how they did/didn’t help. ❤️✏️
“200 sheet construction paper landscape.”

I’m underwater with a deadline (watch the NYT!) and the world is so hard right now, but it feels extra important this year to stand up and be counted, so i didn’t want to miss coming out day (yesterday!) and let the opportunity pass to say Yay Gay and remind any newcomers that I’m a proud queer/bi/call me what you will. I’m also Jewish which i know the name MacNaughton betrays. Your fave passing art auntie is still over here flying her flag high since 1975 (well, 1993, when I hung those freedom rings on the rearview mirror) and even though people are literally trying to wipe queers and Jews off the face of the planet right now, I’m grateful to live in a time and place where we have more of a chance to be our full beautiful selves, and create and learn and struggle and grow and love, together. Thank you to all those who bravely came out when/where it is a huge risk to do so, and my biggest love to those of you who will come out when it’s the right time for you to as well. 
❤️🏳️‍🌈❤️
**please read my comment below**

Online today and full-page in the Sunday @nytimes: a story on how drawing can help us See one another again. 
A little while back, I did a public art project where I set up a table in SF, NY and LA and called strangers over to draw each other (meaning, look closely at one another) for one minute. As simple as the piece was, the impact was profound: joy, laughter, attention, presence and connection between two strangers who would never otherwise have sat down together. 
The piece in the @nytimes tells that story, and is a call for all of us around the world to simply see one another. Because how can we move forward together if we don’t first do that. 
I created a toolkit that anyone can use to host a DrawTogether Strangers pop-up piece in your own home town/city/park/library. It’s easy to use on your phone and there’s a downloadable script, etc. 
And the piece in the newspaper on Sunday actually has space to draw in it. I hope people use it.
*Links to the NYT piece and the Toolkit in my bio.* 
I know this is a little drop in the bucket but I believe in this project, the experience it offers people, with my whole heart. I know I’m just an artist and know nothing of policy, but I believe acts of creativity and connection are the only way foreword.

There are only a few slides here… the whole thing won’t fit. Again, all the links are in my bio. 

Huge huge thanks for making all aspects of this happen, from the public pieces in the parks to the NYT to the toolkit. @jopearl ❤️🙏@damiensaatdjian @mr_augugliaro @chriscolin3000 @kylerw @baggermaniac @kyrsthensley @courtwrites @jmooallem

“The Importance of Looking at What (and Who) We Don’t See” in todays @nytimes, the back page of the @nytopinion section. Those two boxes are blank in the paper leaving room for you and a stranger to draw each other.

Thank you editor @jopearl for championing this piece, and ADs @damiensaatdjian & @mr_augugliaro for visual everything. 

There is a toolkit available online (link in my bio) to host your own DrawTogether Strangers pop-up table in your community, and offer the chance for people to start to see one another again. More on that soon. 

Thanks @annehattie for the early AM photo, and Anne and Arlo for the phenomenal drawings. And SFO why don’t y’all carry the NYT anymore?!? Someone save me a copy pls!

World if you don’t already know the work of Courtney Martin @courtwrites this is such a perfect intro. In her writing, reporting, editing, gathering, interviewing, and the million other things she does, she is always seeking out the deepest hidden human truths, gently and kindly drawing them into the light so we all can learn together. Courtney has a new podcast out called The Wise Unknown where, in true court form, she asks well-known people to share the wisest lesser known people they know, and then she interviews that person. So simple and smart and the result is moving, beautiful, and we have so so much to learn from each of these people. 
The nominators include @wkamaubell @ciaosamin @adamgrant @aijenp @rosariodawson @ashley_judd @allendeisabel - whew! 
Listen wherever you listen to your podcasts. 
And oh yeah, I was/am super honored to do the show art 🤗

Keeping it serious since 1975.

47 was one big, terrifying test on leaning into overwhelming, scary, no idea what’s on the other side sort of feelings. And how little control we have over The Big Stuff. From crying-curled-up-on-the-kitchen-floor, to falling-head-over-heels-in-love, it’s been a lesson on living inside to out. Everything everywhere all at once. And the unexpected rewards that come from keeping an open heart.

Thanks for rolling with me through it: the art, the projects, the people, and beyond. It's a thin tether this internet social handheld device. I would never call it a home, but it's led to real life love and joy and work and honest to gosh life changing stuff. I guess like everything we can make of it what we want. 

48! Onwards.

AUDIOFLUX IS ALIIIVEEEE!!!! Three of my unpublished drawings served as the prompts for six amazing audio stories created by the inaugural @audiofluxing creative cohort! You can listen to all the stories at AudioFlux.org 💥
TELL US MORE, WENDY. 
Founded by @jatomic & @reverendjohn3000, AudioFlux - aka @audiofluxing - is an interdisciplinary creative experiment pairing audio storytellers and podcasters with artists working in other mediums, giving them prompts and rules, and then stepping back and seeing (and hearing!) what happens. I couldn’t be prouder to be part of @audiofluxing first creative cohort, and then get to share our work at the inaugural @thei_m_i conference yesterday.
For this first cohort, six producers (Aaron Edwards, Chloe Prasinos, Megan Tan, Yowei Shaw, Mathilde Urfalino, and Gregory Warner) each made a 3 minute audio story based on three of my unpublished drawings and the theme of “letting go” that included archival audio. They gave those audio pieces to me and then I responded to each audio piece with a new drawing. 
You can see some of the response drawings on the screen behind us and again, listen to their stories at AudioFlux.org 

We presented it all on stage at @thei_m_i festival yesterday & the reception was 💥.

I can’t say loud enough what a joy it is to make something new and unexpected in collaboration with artists who see (hear!) the world differently way right now. Unexpected. Fresh. Hopeful. And fun. 

Just what we all need. 

You can listen to the audio pieces and see the prompt drawings and visual responses on the @audiofluxing website. And follow them for an unfolding of cross-pollinating creativity. Thanks for inviting me Julie!! 
🌱 👂 ✏️ ❤️

One of the best ways to combat a deficit mentality (linked to an either/or outlook, and the origin of so much conflict and struggle) is to cultivate gratitude. Studies show that in addition to combating depression and burn out, practicing gratitude helps develop an abundance mindset. A *Both/And* outlook. 
Thanksgiving is a whack holiday on many levels - its history of manipulation and genocide - *and* it’s also an often joyful celebration of family and care. I’m trying so hard to hold multiple things in my heart these days - and a week of a daily drawing gratitude practice is the best way I can think to support that. So starting tomorrow that’s what I’m doing. If you’d like to join me (I’ll send you daily drawing/writing prompts and you can share your art with the community) sign up for the Grown-Ups Table (the GUT) - link in my bio. 
(If you don’t have the funds hit me up via the website. I got you. Nobody turned away from the Table.) 
❤️✏️❤️

“I forgive you.” “Please forgive me.” “I love you.” In this tenderly illustrated book, graphic journalist Wendy MacNaughton shares what she learned from hospice caregivers about how to be with someone as they die. She distills hours of sitting, being there and waiting into a beautiful reminder that death is a part of living and that we can learn from it. “Follow their lead.” “Just be there.” “Cry. A lot.” This “how-to” guide about dying reminds the living to embrace the present and deepen our relationships.
— LA Johnson, art director

Thank you @npr for including How to Say Goodbye in your 2023 “Books We Love” list! And alongside @marikotamaki & @jilliantamaki’s Roaming?? COME ON. (I LOVED Roaming - a coming of age graphic novel set in NYC. Arty, queer, messy and free, all about friendship and growing up into who we are and who we want to be.) Also @pjorenstein’s Unraveling? And @clairedederer’s Monsters?? Ridiculous. ❤️❤️❤️

Ps. Love you beloved agent @charlottesheedy & publisher @bloomsburypublishing - thanks Sheedy lit for the cute slide

Every day this week I’ve been giving the #drawtogetherGUT (The Grown-Ups Table) a daily gratitude drawing assignment. We’ve drawn our senses, joyful moments, hard times, friendships and food. The idea is to use drawing and writing (aka creativity) to strengthen our gratitude muscle. Studies show practicing gratitude helps develop an abundance mindset instead of a scarcity mindset, the latter of which is the foundation of so much conflict and war. A scarcity mindset sees things as having to be  you OR me. As Either/Or. An abundance mindset sees a Both/And approach to people & the world. You AND me.
As we enter what can be both a joyful AND challenging holiday for people (family, history, all of it) I’m doing my best to find things to be grateful for today, and hold the Both/And. If you want to join me, great. Let’s make Both/And the toast at the table today. If you (like me) have a REAL HARD TIME with this, I got  some drawing assignments for you that might help. 
Grateful for y’all. ❤️

Gratitude drawings: 
1. Nonie’s frozen chocolate
2. @revolutionarease 
3. @courtwrites 
4. The green sofa 
5. The senses 
6. Redwood trees
7. My newest tattoo ❤️❤️

Today in the @nytimes! A beautiful audio story on the DrawTogether Strangers project produced by the brilliant @vishakhadarbha! Vishakha and editor @jopearl came with me as I set up the DT Strangers drawing table on the Highline and recorded what happened. The result is an incredibly thoughtful piece on the purpose and impact of the project, where I get strangers to draw each other - by which I mean look closely and really *see* one another - to see past bias and expectations, and  begin to build trust and new connections. I really, really feel that the basic act of seeing one another is what we aren’t doing right now and it’s the starting point we need to work from if we want to create something new, and better, together. 
The link to listen is in my bio. 
If you want to learn more about the DT Strangers project and download the toolkit so you can host your own DrawTogether Strangers table in your community, a link for that is in my bio too and on my website.

Clip: Active listening 👂🏼

▶️ NOW PLAYING - Full episode at 🔗 in bio or wherever you listen to your favorite shows.

This was an absolutely meaningful conversation on @griefisasneakybitch  podcast with the delightful @wendymac - drawn journalist, artist, social worker illustrator and author of How to Say Goodbye.

As artist-in-residence at the Zen Hospice Project Guest House in San Francisco, Wendy MacNaughton witnessed firsthand how difficult it is to know what to do when we’re sharing final moments with a loved one. In this tenderly illustrated guide to saying goodbye, MacNaughton shows how to make sure those moments are meaningful. Using a framework of “the five things” taught to her by a professional caregiver, How to Say Goodbye provides a model for having conversations of love, respect, and closure: with the words “I forgive you,” “Please forgive me,” “Thank you,” “I love you,” and “Goodbye,” each oriented toward finding mutual peace and understanding when it matters most. 

In her book, and in our conversation in this episode, Wendy offers us a beautiful, poetic, masterful meditation on the art of presence as love.

▶️ NOW PLAYING - Full episode at 🔗 in bio or wherever you listen to your favorite shows.

#grief #grieving #griefsupport #hospice #listening #activelistening #howtosaygoodbye #bookstagram #griefisasneakybitch #podcast #podcastersofinstagram

McKenna Hadley-Burke, a radio producer with the show Tapestry on the CBC (that’s Canadian NPR), created an exceptionally beautiful audio story about letting go, why we make art, and my little book How to Say Goodbye. When we spoke a few weeks ago, our conversation brought me to tears. That doesn’t happen to me a lot. And now, listening to what she made, I’m crying again… McKenna somehow got me to share maybe the deepest, most vulnerable reason I draw: to not forget. Because I forget a lot. And drawing helps me slow down and be in my body, commune with what I’m experiencing, and outsource my brain to paper. It’s a way to record people and moments with care so maybe they won’t fade from my brain in five minutes. Maybe I’ll still forget. Maybe nobody will remember anything we make. (Nobody will.) But that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t make it, does it? I was moved by the poem @andreagibson shared recently and I fully agree: nobody leaves. But what I’m asking is what happens to our memories when they disappear. Where do they go? Who are we when we forget? And if we keep drawing - writing - making, do we get to remember? 

If you want to listen to the story the link is in my bio. 

Happy holidays y’all. ❤️

Volume 12.
Via world’s best @birbigs

End of an era. We moved the DrawTogether set out of its home at @themarshtheater in SF, distributed some of the most sentimental items to contributors (if you’re one and there’s something you’d like to keep, please holler) and tucked the big stuff into storage. 
I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again: I could not be prouder of what this mighty little team of friends created together, and all its ripple effects. There are SO MANY more  contributors than the core crew pictured here - but these are the folks who put their whole hearts (and years!) into DrawTogether. @modernhouse (two from the left) designed and built the DT set from cardboard and wood, with round the clock help from @carolinembpaul (on the far right)- literally MONTHS of hard work. @carolinembpaul also did EVERYTHING with filming since day one of the live pandemic shows - with the help of Suso, of course, who was the true star of the show. @katelevitt (far left) jumped in and helped evolve DrawTogether into a full educational program that’s now in over 13,000 classrooms around the world. 
DrawTogether contributors and supporters not pictured, you know who you are. It couldn’t have happened without you.
It feels good to wrap up this life chapter/project with a bow knowing we gave it our all. 
It’s insane to build something out of thin air, create a whole world with our hands that fills so many hearts, especially ours, then break it all back down again. Let it go. It’s really darn sad to say goodbye. But it also feels right and good. In art as in life, I guess. 
Thanks everyone who’s been a part of it. Love you to the moon. 
Onwards.

Anyone feeling like they want (need!) a daily dose of drawing to start off the new year? Establish a new habit that will help with our hearts during what’s shaping up to be a helluva year? Maybe break ourselves of other old ones (read: checking social media first thing in the AM)? ME TOO. 

I’m starting a new 30-Day Drawing Habit w the world’s most awesome (and least intimidating) drawing/creative community The Grown-Ups Table (aka The GUT) on January 1. 

10 minutes of easy, fun, de-stressing drawing (and more) a day with the amazing GUT creative community around the world. I give you weekly lessons and prompts, and inspiration and check ins through the week, and the whole community (including me) keeps in touch and shares our work DAILY in the Grown-Ups Table chat. Swipe to read what people said after doing the 30 days with me last time - it was a wild success. 
I can only assume this time is going to be even better. Cause whew. We all NEED IT. At least I sure do. 

**Link to learn more & sign up in my bio!**
